This is a good post by Balaji. Interesting ideas. I think it fits with the hypothesis of America on a historical arc like that of Rome:

Rome: Early Republic -> Pax Romana Empire -> Decentralization of power toward aristocratic estates, provincial themes, and feudal lords via pronoia system.

Aranya is a lifestyle brand and seaside community located in the Beidaihe New District of Qinhuangdao City, Hebei Province, China. The name ‚ÄúAranya‚Äù is derived from the Sanskrit word ‚ÄúAranya,‚Äù meaning ‚Äúa place of quietness, leisure, retreat, or a place away from the hustle and bustle of the world for spiritual practice.‚Äù  

Development History:

2013: Aranya was established as a seaside community in the Beidaihe New District of Qinhuangdao, Hebei Province.  

2015: The Seaside Public Library, also known as the ‚ÄúLonely Library,‚Äù was completed and quickly gained popularity, enhancing Aranya‚Äôs reputation and marking its transformation from a real estate project to a cultural brand.

2018: Aranya collaborated with the Ullens Center for Contemporary Art (UCCA) to further expand its cultural influence.

2023: Aranya began operations in new locations, including Jinshanling and Wuling Mountain, expanding its market presence.  

Through these stages, Aranya has successfully transformed into a comprehensive brand that integrates culture, art, and tourism.

Aranya has developed a comprehensive management system that allows visitors to purchase tickets for community tours. 

Within the community, there are communal canteens offering diverse dining options. The community regularly organizes various cultural and artistic activities, attracting numerous theater artists. 

Additionally, Aranya features a variety of trendy brand stores for fashion enthusiasts. To facilitate transportation, the community provides shuttle bus services connecting internal and external areas. 

For accommodation, Aranya offers multiple hotels and homestays to cater to different visitor preferences. 

Moreover, convenient food delivery services are available within the community, enhancing dining choices.

‚û°Ô∏è **Finally, on India and China.**

Short term, there is a rivalry.

Long term, what if‚Ä¶.I mean what if, the Dharmic and Sinic ‚Äî two of the oldest civilizations ‚Äî become aligned? As Balaji has pointed out, India is waking up to its Dharmic roots, just has China has been embracing its Sinic roots. Long term, philosophically, there are more similarities than differences. NS is in a region - Malaysia and Singapore ‚Äî where millions of people of Indian and Chinese descent live quite harmoniously.

Which brings to another point ‚û°Ô∏è **regarding China and Russia**.

China (by this I mean the ruling party) probably does not care that much about Taiwan‚Äôs chips in the long term ‚Äî mainland China has been developing domestic chip industry anyways. The West sees Taiwan as a strategic technology/economic asset to defend, wheras for CCP/CPC it‚Äôs about historical legitimacy and mandate. In a dogfight, who is more crazy, the dude who fights to secure resources, or the dude who fights for perceived family honor? (Btw, regular Chinese citizens, like regular American citizens, do not care that much about Taiwan‚Ä¶most worry about employment, healthcare, education, etc)

For Russia (by this I mean the rulers), arguably, it is about reclaiming relevance. Reclaiming the relevance lost since the fall of the Soviet Empire. Russia has historically always looked up to its Orthodox/Byzantine ties. It‚Äôs like Justinan trying to reclaim Roman glory or Manuel Komnenos trying to reclaim pre-Manzikert glory.

‚û°Ô∏è **On China** ‚Äî and again, this may or may not be a popular view ‚Äî I think the Chip War in the long term is arguably the best thing that could happen to China.

In the 1950‚Äôs - 1960‚Äôs, America embargoed China from technologies, China developed the Atomic Bomb virtually on its own.
In the early 2000‚Äôs, America cut China out of the international space collaboration, China developed its own space station ‚Äî which is ironically the only one standing today.
More recently, America tries to cut China out of the global chip supply, Chinese entrepreneurs develop DeepSeek (which is open source) and China has no choice but to develop its own indigious chip industry‚Ä¶how long do we think it will be until a ‚ÄúDeepSeek‚Äù moment happens in chips? 

For 70+ years, America has been very successful in keeping Germany and Japan down, because it has co-opted Germany/Japan into dependency. It‚Äôs called ‚Äúboiling a frog‚Äù. Cutting a potential rival off often back fires into the very thing that one tries to prevent ‚Äî because it incentivizes independence and nothing-to-lose mentality from the other side.

The American resilience and confidence is admirable. Reminds me of Rome during the Punic Wars. Never count out Rome/America. When Hannibal marched to the gates of Rome, no Roman talked about surrender or appeasing the Carthgenians (compared to how later Carthage appeased Rome to the point of even driving out Hannibal). That confidence is energizing and captivating. You just don‚Äôt count out America or Americans.

On the other hand, the confidence arises from America arguably not having really experienced its full historical arc yet. Aside from a brief scare in 1812, America has never lost its core and never been existentially challenged ‚Äî yes, it is blessed geographically ‚Äî and Civil War, as brutal as it was, doesn‚Äôt compare to the brutality of Poland being carved out completely, or Soviet Russia during Barbarossa, or any number of atrocities experienced by many European/Asian nations during their longer historical arcs. WWI, WWII, Cold War etc were competitions that did not threathen the American heartland (again, blessed geographically). Competition with China is also far from the heartland.

The Roman in 180 AD was confident in Pax Romana, the Han Chinese in 180 AD was confident of Han Dynasty‚Äôs eternal mandate, but neither forsaw the Crisis of the Third Century. It took the East Romans losing Anatolian heartland after Manzikert and the Han Chinese having 80% of central plains decimated by Mongol invasions to realize that they were not exceptional at all.

Really enjoying this conversation. Healthy, respectul debate is also good. I can‚Äôt wait to meet everyone when I am back at NS May 1st. 

Some thoughts to build on this ongoing discussion in terms of related topics‚Ä¶

‚û°Ô∏è **On America **‚Äî and this may or may not be a popular view ‚Äî I grew up in America, I think it is at the same time under-estimated and over-estimated.

I think arguably another thing that separates American mindset from other Old World nations (besides high agency) is the confidence, whch works both ways.

**Top Founder Residency Programs in 2025**

After researching the best residency programs for founders, here are the top options:

**1. HF0 (Hacker Fellowship Zero)**
- 3-month live-in program in San Francisco/Miami
- Focus on technical founders (especially AI)
- "Hacker monastery" experience in Archbishop's Mansion
- Highly competitive, two cohorts yearly
- Best for: Technical founders ready for intense focus

**2. Network School**
- 90-day program in Forest City, Malaysia
- Founded by Balaji Srinivasan
- Focus on "network states" and decentralized communities
- Deposits up to $2,000
- Best for: Crypto enthusiasts and decentralization advocates

**3. Antler Founder Residency**
- 6-week intensive building sprint
- 20+ global locations
- Pre-seed support with "6 months progress in 6 weeks"
- Best for: Global-minded early-stage founders

**4. On Deck Founder Fellowship (ODF)**
- 10-week remote program
- Helps founders go from pre-idea to pre-seed
- Launched 1,000+ companies worth $10B+
- Best for: Remote-friendly networking and ideation

**5. Roux Institute Founder Residency**
- Comprehensive resources (legal, data science, mentorship)
- Strong network connections
- Best for: Complex ventures needing multifaceted support

**For International Founders:**
Key visa options include EB-5, E-2, EB-2 NIW, and EB-1A, with requirements varying by investment amounts, country of origin, and demonstrated exceptional ability.

One additional comment on Russia: in the West we tend to see it as one entity, but in essence it is called the Russian Federation. It is a large sprawling Euroasian landmass with not just ethnic Russians, but also Tatars, Bashkirs, Chuvashs, Chechens, and Armenians, to name a few, and other Turkic groups. Close to 25% of Russia is not ethnic Russian. A republic within the Russian Federation also does not arguably operate in the same sense of a US state or a Chinese province...there is arguably more autonomy is certain cases, which lends an additional dimension to how Russia operates.

* Prior to Nixon's 1972 coup pulling PRC from Soviet Union, PRC and Soviet Union already experienced 10+ years of tension and drifting apart, including border skirmishes, dating back to Mao and Khrushchev's animosity in the earliy 1960's.

Sundial: Making Time Series Predictions
Let me explain this cool new way scientists figured out to predict what happens next in a time series!
What's a time series?
First, a time series is just a bunch of numbers that come one after another over time - like if you wrote down the temperature every day for a whole year, or how many customers visited a store each hour.
What did these scientists create?
They created something called "Sundial," which is like a super-smart computer program that can look at any time series (like temperatures, sales, or website visitors) and predict what might happen next!
Why is it special?

It learns from TONS of data - they trained it on 1 trillion numbers from all sorts of time series!
It doesn't just give one prediction - it gives several possible futures because the future isn't certain
It works right away - you don't need to train it specially for your particular data

How does it work?
They created a special way for the computer to learn called "TimeFlow Loss." This helps the computer understand patterns in numbers that change over time. It's a bit like how your brain might notice that after it rains, the temperature usually drops - but way more complicated!
They use something called a "Transformer" (similar to what powers AI like ChatGPT), but they made special changes to make it work better with time series data.
What can it do?
Sundial can:

Predict energy usage
Forecast weather patterns
Guess future sales
And lots more!

The coolest part is that when they tested it against other prediction programs, Sundial did better than almost all of them - even though the other programs had to be specially trained for each specific prediction task!
Why does this matter?
Imagine if you're planning how much electricity your city needs next week, or how many ice cream cones to make at your shop tomorrow. Having good predictions helps you make better decisions. And since Sundial shows you several possible futures (not just one), you can better prepare for different possibilities!

(11-20)

11. The concept of "society as a service" emerged, with discussion of how to prevent profit motives from corrupting the user experience or sacrificing the community's needs.

12. Members debated the balance between idealism and practicality in creating new societies, especially regarding economic sustainability.

13. The group discussed the concept of "parallel societies" that could provide alternative services as existing institutions decline or fail to meet needs.

14. Participants emphasized the need for iterative development and MVP (Minimum Viable Product) approaches to building societies, starting small but with complete systems.

15. The accessibility of startup societies was questioned - whether they would be limited to elites or could be made accessible to those with talent but limited financial resources.

16. Energy independence and infrastructure were identified as critical considerations for physical resilience of network states.

17. The importance of having a "common vision" was highlighted as a unifying factor that traditional governments often fail to provide.

18. Several speakers noted the value of maintaining diversity of societal options rather than trying to create one perfect society for everyone.

19. The concept of an expiration date for moral standards was proposed, allowing societies to periodically revisit and update their values rather than becoming rigid.

20. The group discussed how crypto properties and values might be applied to governance systems to create more transparent, fair, and uncorruptible societies.

here's Claude's top 20 points synthesizing/ summarizing today's convo üòÑ 

(1-10)

1. The group explored whether a "new country" is the necessary end state of a community or startup society, or if societies can exist solely to create moral innovation without aspiring to statehood.

2. Startup societies were discussed as building blocks or foundations for potential network states, with the focus on creating effective templates that could be replicated.

3. Balaji Srinivasan's concept of "moral innovation" was examined - the idea that founders of startup societies are "moral entrepreneurs" offering potential citizens a better way of life by correcting something the broader world has gotten wrong.

4. Multiple speakers highlighted the importance of creating societies that prioritize individual happiness and well-being rather than focusing exclusively on economic metrics like GDP.

5. The group discussed how startup societies could differentiate themselves from businesses or governments by having different values, goals, and incentive structures.

6. Participants explored how transparency and governance systems could be improved using blockchain-like properties (permissionless, uncorruptible, transparent, verifiable systems).

7. Resilience was identified as an essential quality for startup societies - being able to withstand external pressures and attacks, similar to how Bitcoin has demonstrated resilience.

8. The group debated various metrics to measure a society's success beyond economic outcomes, including well-being indexes, retention rates, and adoption metrics.

9. Several members emphasized the evolutionary and emergent nature of societies, suggesting that founders can set up environments but should allow organic development.

10. The importance of creating proper incentive structures was discussed, with the acknowledgment that human nature responds to incentives while avoiding purely negative reinforcement.
